You are right, the source/object approach is one
difference.  Another is that GJTK can separate data by
test, it's up to you whether that's important or not. 


Some of the other features like runtime performance
are more significant if you also collect coverage at
higher levels, integration and systems level testing. 


To be honest I don't know that there would be much of
a speed difference compared to another
instrumentation-based solution like Clover, but the
differences are dramatic compared to the JPDA-based
tools.

I'm not in sales so I guess I'll leave it at that.  
;-)  Both tools are readily available for download so
it's not hard to try them out and see which works
better for you.

Scott


--- Eytan Faverman <shmaytan@...> wrote:
> Andy,
> 
> thanks for the info. Clover does seem pretty solid.
> Wondering how it
> compares with http://www.testersedge.com/gjtk/.
> Seems the main
> difference is that one instruments the byte code
> while the other
> instuments the source (since speed of testing is not
> a huge concern
> does it really even matter?).
> 
> Thanks,
> -Eytan
> 
>
